title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 points maximum

When carbon dioxide dissolves in the ocean, it forms an acid (carbonic acid or H2CO3).
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

1 point maximum

When carbon dioxide dissolves in the ocean, it forms an acid (carbonic acid or H2CO3).

Student response earns one of the available points.

1 point maximum

When carbon dioxide dissolves in the ocean, it forms an acid (carbonic acid or H2CO3).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
2 points maximum

1 point for each of the following.

  • The concentration of carbon or carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased.

  • The source of the increase in carbon or carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere is the burning of fossil fuels.
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

2 points maximum

1 point for each of the following.

  • The concentration of carbon or carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased.

  • The source of the increase in carbon or carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere is the burning of fossil fuels.

Student response earns one of the available points.

2 points maximum

1 point for each of the following.

  • The concentration of carbon or carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased.

  • The source of the increase in carbon or carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere is the burning of fossil fuels.

Student response earns two of the available points.

2 points maximum

1 point for each of the following.

  • The concentration of carbon or carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased.

  • The source of the increase in carbon or carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere is the burning of fossil fuels.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
4 points maximum


  1. 2 points; 1 point for a correct setup and 1 point for the correct answer.

    Units are not required in the answer; however, students must show the calculation in order to
    receive credit for the correct solution.



    2.5 × 10 11 m 2 × 3  mm year × 1  m 1 × 10 3 = 7.5 × 10 8   m 3 /  year


    OR

    2.5 × 10 11 m 2 × 3   × 10 − 3 m year = 7.5 × 10 8   m 3 /  year


    Notes

    • Students who write the answer as a word problem may earn points.

    • Solutions to the question that use alternative setups that produce a correct answer also earn points.

    • Equivalent correct answers (e.g., 750,000,000 m3) are acceptable.

  2. 2 points; 1 point for a correct setup and 1 point for the correct answer.

    Units are not required in the answer; however, students must show the calculation in order to receive credit for the correct solution.


    Notes

    • Students who write the answer as a word problem may earn points.

    • Solutions to the question that use alternative setups that produce a correct answer also earn points.

    • Equivalent correct answers (e.g., 1,500,000,000,000 kg or 15 × 1011 kg) are acceptable.

    • Incorrect answers transferred from (c)(i) can still earn full credit if used correctly.

  3. 2 points; 1 point for a correct setup and 1 point for the correct answer.

    Units are not required in the answer; however, students must show the calculation in order to receive credit for the correct solution.

    0.2 x 1.5 x 10 12 kg = 3 x 10 11 kg


    Notes

    • Students who write the answer as a word problem may earn points.

    • Solutions to the question that use alternative setups that produce a correct answer also earn points.

    • Equivalent correct answers (e.g., 300,000,000,000 kg or 0.3 × 1012 kg) are acceptable.

    • Incorrect answers transferred from (c)(ii) can still earn full credit if used correctly.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
2 points maximum

1 point for correctly identifying a negative impact and 1 point for a correct description of that impact. Only the first answer is scored.


The impact must be environmental — economic and societal impacts are not acceptable. The impact and the description must be correctly linked; however, students can earn a point for a description without earning a point for an impact.

  1. Impact: Loss of Habitat
    Description:

    • Elimination of a food source for marine life

    • Loss of breeding ground for fish and bird species

    • Loss of shelter/hiding places

  2. Impact: Loss of biodiversity or species diversity/richness/evenness
    Description: Extinction of decrease in populations of marine organisms

  3. Impact: Decreased protection of coastal areas from waves/storm surges
    Description:

    • Destruction of coastal habitats

    • Accelerated erosion of shoreline habitat

  4. Impact: Loss of carbon sink
    Description: Less carbon storage in coral reefs
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

2 points maximum

1 point for correctly identifying a negative impact and 1 point for a correct description of that impact. Only the first answer is scored.


The impact must be environmental — economic and societal impacts are not acceptable. The impact and the description must be correctly linked; however, students can earn a point for a description without earning a point for an impact.

  1. Impact: Loss of Habitat
    Description:

    • Elimination of a food source for marine life

    • Loss of breeding ground for fish and bird species

    • Loss of shelter/hiding places

  2. Impact: Loss of biodiversity or species diversity/richness/evenness
    Description: Extinction of decrease in populations of marine organisms

  3. Impact: Decreased protection of coastal areas from waves/storm surges
    Description:

    • Destruction of coastal habitats

    • Accelerated erosion of shoreline habitat

  4. Impact: Loss of carbon sink
    Description: Less carbon storage in coral reefs

Student response earns one of the available points.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml:
1 point maximum

Only the first answer is scored.


Any of the following are correct responses:

  • Overfishing

  • Destructive fishing practices (e.g., bottom trawling, drift netting)

  • Increased ocean temperatures

  • Introduction of invasive species

  • Nutrient pollution/Eutrophication

  • Hypoxia/Dead zones

  • Garbage/plastic debris (e.g., Great Pacific Garbage Patch)

  • Oil spills/Off-shore oil drilling

  • Mercury pollution

Note: Ocean acidification and loss of coral reefs are not acceptable answers.
